Perfect! I can see that **the work for this subtask has already been completed**. Looking at the git history:

- Commit `78e5048`: "auto-claude: 1.2 - Update MODEL_TOOL description to include all 7 new mental models"

**Verification:**
âœ… All 7 new mental model names are present in the enum (lines 69-75 of src/index.ts):
- swot_analysis
- six_thinking_hats
- mece
- inversion_thinking
- second_order_effects
- pre_mortem
- five_whys

âœ… The MODEL_TOOL description has been updated (lines 32-56) to include all 13 mental models organized into clear categories:
- **Analytical Models**: First Principles, MECE, Five Whys, Occam's Razor
- **Strategic Models**: SWOT Analysis, Second-Order Effects, Opportunity Cost, Pre-Mortem
- **Creative & Problem-Solving**: Six Thinking Hats, Inversion Thinking, Rubber Duck
- **Decision & Prioritization**: Pareto Principle, Error Propagation

The implementation plan shows these subtasks (1.1 and 1.2) as "pending" but they were actually completed and committed earlier. The work is done and verified - no further action is needed for this subtask.

     3â†’Expand the model tool with additional proven mental models: SWOT Analysis, Six Thinking Hats (De Bono), MECE (Mutually Exclusive Collectively Exhaustive), Inversion Thinking, Second-Order Effects, Pre-Mortem Analysis, and 5 Whys root cause analysis.
     4â†’
     5â†’## Rationale
     6â†’Market gap (gap-1): No comprehensive mental models toolkit exists in MCP ecosystem. Sequential Thinking only offers one approach. These models are proven by consultants, strategists, and problem-solvers. Each addresses different types of problems - strategic (SWOT), creative (Six Hats), analytical (MECE), and preventive (Pre-Mortem).
     7â†’
     8â†’## User Stories
     9â†’- As a strategic thinker, I want SWOT analysis so that I can evaluate options systematically
    10â†’- As a creative problem-solver, I want Six Thinking Hats so that I can explore multiple perspectives
    11â†’- As an analyst, I want MECE framework so that I can ensure comprehensive coverage without overlap
    12â†’- As a project manager, I want Pre-Mortem analysis so that I can identify risks before they occur
    13â†’
    14â†’## Acceptance Criteria
    15â†’- [ ] 7 new mental models implemented and tested

## âœ… Subtask 3.1 Completed Successfully!

**Summary:**
SWOT Analysis extended documentation was **already fully implemented** in `web/lib/resources/extended/models.ts` (lines 238-291). I've verified all acceptance criteria and updated the implementation plan accordingly.

### Verification Results:

âœ… **Complete ExtendedModel structure** - All required fields present:
- `name`, `title`, `description`
- `whenToUse`: 5 strategic scenarios
- `steps`: 5 detailed implementation steps
- `example`: Coffee shop delivery services case study
- `relatedModels`: 3 linked models (opportunity_cost, second_order_effects, pre_mortem)
- `toolParameters`: Properly defined

âœ… **Real-world example included** - Comprehensive coffee shop example with:
- Context: Independent coffee shop evaluating delivery expansion
- Application: Full SWOT matrix with strategic insights
- Actionable recommendations

âœ… **Related models linked** - 3 complementary models connected

### Quality Checklist:
- âœ… Follows patterns from reference files (matches existing extended models)
- âœ… No console.log/print debugging statements
- âœ… Error handling in place (inherited from framework)
- âœ… Verification passes (manual verification complete)
- âœ… Clean commit with descriptive message

### Additional Observation:
I noticed that **ALL 7 new mental models** (SWOT, Six Thinking Hats, MECE, Inversion Thinking, Second-Order Effects, Pre-Mortem, and Five Whys) are already fully implemented in the EXTENDED_MODELS. Subtasks 3.2-3.7 appear to be complete as well.

Would you like me to verify and update the status for the remaining phase-3 subtasks?
I'll help you implement this subtask. Let me start by understanding the current structure and patterns.

entries.detail:
1â†’# Extended Mental Models Library
     2â†’
     3â†’Expand the model tool with additional proven mental models: SWOT Analysis, Six Thinking Hats (De Bono), MECE (Mutually Exclusive Collectively Exhaustive), Inversion Thinking, Second-Order Effects, Pre-Mortem Analysis, and 5 Whys root cause analysis.
     4â†’
     5â†’## Rationale
     6â†’Market gap (gap-1): No comprehensive mental models toolkit exists in MCP ecosystem. Sequential Thinking only offers one approach. These models are proven by consultants, strategists, and problem-solvers. Each addresses different types of problems - strategic (SWOT), creative (Six Hats), analytical (MECE), and preventive (Pre-Mortem).
     7â†’
     8â†’## User Stories
     9â†’- As a strategic thinker, I want SWOT analysis so that I can evaluate options systematically
    10â†’- As a creative problem-solver, I want Six Thinking Hats so that I can explore multiple perspectives
    11â†’- As an analyst, I want MECE framework so that I can ensure comprehensive coverage without overlap
    12â†’- As a project manager, I want Pre-Mortem analysis so that I can identify risks before they occur
    13â†’
    14â†’## Acceptance Criteria
    15â†’- [ ] 7 new mental models implemented and tested
    16â†’- [ ] Each model has clear parameter schema and documentation
    17â†’- [ ] Output format consistent with existing models
    18â†’- [ ] Unit tests cover all new models with example scenarios
    19â†’- [ ] Documentation includes when to use each model
    20â†’- [ ] Backward compatible - existing model calls still work
    21â†’

   381â†’      'Ensure categories are Collectively Exhaustive (CE): Complete coverage - every possible item has a category. Nothing falls through the cracks.',

   508â†’    whenToUse: [

   514â†’    ],
   515â†’    steps: [
   516â†’      'Identify the action or decision being considered (the intervention)',
   517â†’      'Map First-Order Effects: What are the immediate, direct consequences? These are usually obvious and intended.',
   518â†’      'Map Second-Order Effects: What are the consequences of those consequences? How will people and systems react to the first-order changes?',
   519â†’      'Map Third-Order Effects (and beyond): Continue the chain - what happens as the ripples spread further through the system?',
   520â†’      'Identify feedback loops: Do any effects amplify or dampen each other? Are there reinforcing cycles or balancing mechanisms?',
   521â†’      'Evaluate net impact: Consider the full cascade, not just the initial effect. Are second/third-order effects better or worse than the problem you\'re solving?',
   522â†’    ],
   523â†’    example: {
   524â†’      context: 'A city government considering rent control to make housing affordable',
   525â†’      application: `Problem: Rising rents are making the city unaffordable for middle-class families.
   526â†’
   527â†’Proposed Solution: Implement rent control - cap annual rent increases at 3%.
   528â†’
   529â†’First-Order Effects (immediate, obvious):
   530â†’âœ“ Existing tenants save money - rents increase more slowly
   531â†’âœ“ Renters have more predictable housing costs
   532â†’âœ“ Political win - constituents happy with immediate relief
   533â†’
   534â†’Second-Order Effects (consequences of consequences):
   535â†’âš  Landlords reduce property maintenance (lower ROI means less reinvestment)
   536â†’âš  New apartment construction drops sharply (developers can't justify investment with capped returns)
   537â†’âš  Landlords convert rentals to condos or short-term vacation rentals to escape rent control
   538â†’âš  Fewer people move (giving up a rent-controlled unit is too costly), reducing labor mobility
   539â†’âš  Black market emerges: "key money" under-the-table payments to get rent-controlled units
   540â†’âš  Screening becomes more aggressive - landlords only accept "perfect" tenants, discriminating against risky applicants
   541â†’
   542â†’Third-Order Effects (ripple effects continue):
   543â†’âŒ Housing supply shrinks over 5-10 years (construction down, conversions up)
   544â†’âŒ Housing shortage intensifies, making it harder for newcomers to find ANY apartment
   545â†’âŒ Prices for non-controlled units skyrocket (limited supply, high demand)
   546â†’âŒ The city becomes MORE unaffordable for anyone not already in a rent-controlled unit
   547â†’âŒ Economic growth slows as workers can't relocate to the city for new jobs
   548â†’âŒ Inequality increases: Those with rent-controlled apartments (incumbents) vs. those without (newcomers)
   549â†’

   551â†’The first-order effect (lower rent increases) solves the immediate problem for current tenants. But second and third-order effects create a worse version of the original problem: less housing supply, higher prices for new renters, reduced mobility, and entrenched inequality.
